posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: I'm trying to CAD a belt system with multiple pulleys and several bends. Using Onshape, there's no path length dimension feature. How can I find the correct positions for the pulleys?

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: FRCDesign.org has a unit on belts and pulleys with its own belt generator so that might help to create complex belt paths

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: I have looked at this, but that lesson only covers simple belt systems (only two pulleys).

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: If you're looking to create more complex shapes, I believe you should select the circles in a clockwise order. The David's Design server on Discord has a lot of people who can assist with such problems.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: Can create the belts; however, I can't find the proper pulley positions for the belt to fit.

posts.name: Nuttyman54
posts.cooked: This is the process that 2910 uses for belts with more than 2 pulleys in Onshape. Screenshot_20250608-194121

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: Does anyone know a good way to cast an 180-degree belt?

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: Is the variable created used in the actual sketch, or is it just for guessing and checking? (Instead of creating a variable, could you just use the measure tool?)

posts.name: Nuttyman54
posts.cooked: It's a method of automation for measurements. Variables in Onshape are structured as features in the tree, preventing use within their own sketch for referencing measurements.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: Use circles with the correct pitch diameter, draw tangent lines to each circle in the chain, and trim excess material. From there, simply measure the belt's length, which gives you the total number of teeth based on the pitch. To find the tooth count, divide the belt length by the pitch; for example, a 300mm belt at 5mm pitch equals 60 teeth.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: Thank You! I have found that you can just look at the belt gen feature script to see the length.
